channel.title: Entertainment on Alien Truth Social

item.title: Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise
item.description:
Extraterrestrials in the Star Trek Franchise ðŸ”—

This article provides a comprehensive list of alien races featured in the Star Trek franchise, spanning from the original series to the latest installments. It emphasizes the significance of these alien encounters as a core element of the Star Trek narrative.

Key ðŸ”—

This section provides a key to the abbreviations used throughout the list to indicate the specific Star Trek media (TV series, films) in which each alien race appears. It includes the title, date, and medium for each abbreviation.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A.”

  • Aenar: A sub-species of Andorians from the planet Andoria, characterized by their light blue/white skin, near-blindness, and telepathic abilities. They are generally pacifistic. Key figures include Hemmer from Strange New Worlds and Talla, Shran’s daughter.
  • Andorian: A blue-skinned, antenna-bearing humanoid species from Andoria. They are depicted as a warrior race and were founding members of the United Federation of Planets.
  • Angosian: A species known for genetically and chemically engineering soldiers for the Tarsian Wars. These “super soldiers” were later confined to a penal settlement.
  • Antedean: An ichthyohumanoid species from Antede III that resembles fish and has a strong aversion to space travel.
  • Arcadian: A member of the United Federation of Planets with a representative on the Federation Council. They have large, round heads and distinctive hairstyles.
  • Arcturian: A species known for their clones, which have a melted skin appearance. They hail from the densely populated world Arcturus.
  • Axanar: The first extraterrestrial race befriended by Earth people aboard the NX-01 Enterprise. Captain Garth of Izar achieved a great victory on behalf of the Federation at the Battle of Axanar.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B.”

  • Bajoran: A humanoid species from the planet Bajor, characterized by nose ridges and deep spirituality. They worship The Prophets and were occupied by the Cardassians. Key locations include Bajor.
  • Ba’ku: A technologically advanced humanoid civilization that chose to abandon technology and live a simple life on an isolated planet with metaphasic radiation. Their aging process is significantly slowed. Key locations include The Briar Patch.
  • Benzite: A humanoid race from the planet Benzar, a member of the United Federation of Planets. They are known for their resistance to poisons and ability to digest almost any organic compound.
  • Betazoid: A telepathic humanoid species from the planet Betazed, a member of the United Federation of Planets. Deanna Troi is a prominent half-Betazoid character.
  • Bolian: Humanoids with blue skin and a ridge running from the back of their heads to their noses. They are active members of the Federation and known for crystal steel and the Bank of Bolius.
  • Borg: A pseudo-species of cybernetically enhanced individuals forming a collective consciousness. They assimilate other species to achieve perfection.
  • Breen: A mysterious race who joined the Dominion during the Dominion War.
  • Brikar: A large, rock-like species. Rok-Tahk from Star Trek: Prodigy is a notable example.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C.”

  • Cardassian: A species with ridges along their foreheads and necks, known for their military dictatorship and conflict with the United Federation of Planets. Key figures include Garak and Gul Dukat. Their homeworld is Cardassia Prime.
  • Chameloid: A race of shapeshifters. Martia is a notable example encountered by Kirk and McCoy.
  • Changeling: A race of fluid shapeshifters who founded the Dominion. Odo is a prominent Changeling character.

D ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “D.”

  • Douwd: Immortal energy beings with vast powers. Only one is known to exist, who committed xenocide against the Husnock.
  • Deltan: A humanoid species from the planet Delta IV, known for their strong sexual attraction. They take a vow of chastity upon joining Starfleet. Ilia and Melle are notable Deltans.

E ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “E.”

  • Edosian: A race of sentient tripedal beings. Lieutenant Arex was introduced in Star Trek: The Animated Series.
  • El-Aurian: A humanoid race known as “Listeners,” with long lifespans and a patient, wise demeanor. Their homeworld, El-Auria, was destroyed by the Borg. Guinan is a notable El-Aurian.

F ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “F.”

  • Ferengi: A species known for their focus on profit and the Rules of Acquisition. Quark is a notable Ferengi character. Their homeworld is Ferenginar.

G ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “G.”

  • Gorn: A violent, lizard-like species known for kidnapping people to serve as incubators for their eggs.

H ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “H.”

  • Hirogen: A violent Delta Quadrant species whose culture is based on hunting other sentient species.
  • Horta: Silicon-based life forms that eat rock on the planet Janus VI.

I ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “I.”

  • Illyrian: A species that practices genetic augmentation to adapt to various environments.

J ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “J.”

  • Jem’Hadar: Genetically engineered shock troops of the Dominion, bred for strength and loyalty to the Founders.

K ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “K.”

  • Kazon: A species introduced in Star Trek: Voyager. They are a nomadic species.
  • Kelpien: A species from the planet Kaminar, suppressed by the Ba’ul for generations. Commander Saru is a notable Kelpien.
  • Klingon: A warrior race with a strict honor code and ridged foreheads. Their homeworld is Kronos.
  • Kzinti: Feline warriors who had four wars with humanity.

L ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “L.”

  • Lanthanite: A long-lived species that has been secretly present on Earth since the 22nd century. Chief Engineer Pelia is a notable Lanthanite.

O ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “O.”

  • Ocampa: A humanoid species from the Delta Quadrant with a history of great mental feats.
  • Organian: Incorporeal energy creatures who render weapons inoperable to prevent conflict.
  • Orion: A green-skinned, humanoid species.

P ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “P.”

  • Pakled: A species that obtains technology from other races, often through trickery.

Q ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “Q.”

  • Q: Immortal, omnipotent beings who belong to the Q Continuum. One Q is particularly interested in humanity.

R ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “R.”

  • Romulan: A violent, treacherous offshoot of the Vulcans who rule the Romulan Empire. Their homeworld is Romulus.
  • Reman: A humanoid caste related to the Romulans, forced to live as enslaved under the Romulans and work in the dilithium mines on Remus.

S ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “S.”

  • Son’a: Former members of the Ba’ku who were exiled for embracing technology.
  • Species 8472: A powerful species from fluidic space that surpasses the Borg in combat prowess.

T ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “T.”

  • Talaxian: A species from the Delta Quadrant. Neelix is a notable Talaxian character.
  • Talosian: A race with the power of illusions from Talos IV.
  • Tellarite: A species known for their love of arguing and blunt speech. Their homeworld is Tellar Prime.
  • Tholian: A xenophobic, non-humanoid hermaphroditic species with a propensity for precision.
  • Tribble: A small, harmless species noted for their rapid reproduction.
  • Trill: A humanoid species where a small minority are joined with a long-lived symbiont. Jadzia Dax and Ezri Dax are notable Trill characters.

V ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “V.”

  • Vidiian: A species encountered in the Delta Quadrant

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Star_Trek_aliens

item.title: Alien Autopsy Fact or Fiction (1995 film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction (1995 film) ðŸ”—

This entry discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The footage, released by British entrepreneur Ray Santilli, was broadcast on television networks worldwide, including Fox television, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, and Channel 4 in the UK. Despite its popularity, the program was thoroughly debunked, with the footage revealed to have been shot on a set in London using plaster casts filled with offal and other materials.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the production of the hoaxed footage. In 2006, Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the 1995 footage in a documentary presented by Eamonn Holmes. They simulated an autopsy on a fabricated alien, constructed by artist and sculptor John Humphreys in a London flat. Humphreys created two dummy alien bodies filled with raspberry jam, sheep brains, and chicken entrails. Alien artifacts were also fabricated. Santilli and Shoefield also admitted to hiring a homeless man in Los Angeles to play the role of the original cameraman.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section outlines how Alien Autopsy was received and referenced in media. The X-Files satirized the footage, and Fox later aired a special debunking it. A fictionalized version of the creation of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the topic, including articles from Skeptical Inquirer and books about the Roswell incident and alien autopsy film.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources, including Ray Santilli’s “My Story” on VJ Enterprises, his IMDb page, and a YouTube link to Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction?

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article discusses extraterrestrials as they appear in works of fiction, distinguishing them from alleged real-life encounters. It notes that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and encourages expansion with additional citations.

Extraterrestrials in Fiction ðŸ”—

This section provides a general overview, defining an extraterrestrial (or alien) as a lifeform originating outside Earth. It highlights the prevalence of extraterrestrials as a theme in science fiction, with examples ranging from ancient works like Lucian of Samosata’s True History to modern depictions.

History ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This subsection traces the earliest portrayals of extraterrestrials, starting with Lucian’s True History, which features a voyage to the Moon and a war between lunar and solar inhabitants. It explains how early concepts of aliens were tied to the development of astronomy and the initial tendency to imagine them as human-like. Voltaire’s MicromÃ©gas and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac are mentioned as examples where extraterrestrials differed from humans only in culture or size.

The impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species is discussed, noting how it revolutionized alien depictions by inspiring authors to imagine non-humanoid lifeforms based on evolutionary principles. Camille Flammarion’s works and H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds are cited as early examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. The section also acknowledges that many works of the era still featured human-like aliens.

The War of the Worlds is further analyzed for its exploration of Darwinian evolution, its depiction of Martians as apex predators, and its critique of British imperialism. It also introduced the tropes of alien invasion and extraterrestrials as monsters. Wells’ The First Men in the Moon is mentioned as an early attempt to detail an alien civilization, drawing parallels to ant colonies. Jules Verne’s contributions to science fiction and space exploration are also noted.

Early 20th Century ðŸ”—

This section discusses the influence of pulp magazines on science fiction, highlighting the prevalence of quasi-human aliens, monstrous invaders, and the trope of human conquest of alien worlds. It mentions Ralph Milne Farley’s The Radio Man as an example. The section notes that most aliens in pulp magazines originated from planets or moons within the Solar System. Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey is recognized for its unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times ðŸ”—

This section examines the evolution of alien depictions in more recent times. The Eternaut by HÃ©ctor GermÃ¡n Oesterheld is highlighted as a pioneering work of alien invasion set in Buenos Aires, serving as a critique of imperialism and the military dictatorship in Argentina.

The Barney and Betty Hill incident is discussed as the first recorded claim of alien abduction, leading to the “grey alien” archetype. Steven Spielberg’s films Close Encounters of the Third Kind and E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial are mentioned as influential works that popularized the grey alien image.

The impact of television and film on alien portrayals is explored, noting the trend towards human-like aliens due to budget constraints, particularly in the Star Trek franchise. Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien are mentioned as franchises that sustained public interest in outer space.

The section concludes by discussing the influence of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on alien depictions, allowing for more bizarre and imaginative lifeforms.

Types ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction. It discusses variations in intelligence, biological aspects (humanoid, Earth-species-like, or weird), and attitudes towards humanity (hostile, friendly, or indifferent). It also mentions the possibility of extraterrestrials originating from unexplored areas of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related Wikipedia articles, including “Parasites in fiction,” “List of fictional extraterrestrials,” “List of films featuring extraterrestrials,” “List of humanoid aliens,” “Mars in fiction,” and “First contact (science fiction).”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of books used as sources for the article.

Further Reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about extraterrestrials in fiction.

External Links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to an external website with additional information on the topic.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrials_in_fiction

item.title: The Flying Saucer (song)
item.description:
The Flying Saucer (song) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the 1956 novelty record “The Flying Saucer” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It details the song’s genre, release information, structure, reception, legacy, and chart performance.

Single Information ðŸ”—

This section identifies “The Flying Saucer” as a single by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, released in July 1956 on the Luniverse label. It classifies the song’s genre as mashup, novelty, break-in, and sound collage. The song’s length is 4:17 (both parts). It also provides a chronology of Buchanan and Goodman’s singles, placing “The Flying Saucer” between their previous and subsequent releases.

Overview ðŸ”—

“The Flying Saucer” is a novelty record and the first in a series of break-in records by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It’s considered an early example of a mashup, using segments of popular songs intertwined with spoken “news” commentary to tell a story about a UFO visit. Bill Buchanan plays the radio announcer, and Dickie Goodman plays reporter John Cameron-Cameron.

Structure ðŸ”—

This section explains the song’s construction using a reel-to-reel tape recorder. It’s described as a two-part sound collage and an audio adaptation of Orson Welles’ “The War of the Worlds,” but comedic. The song intersperses popular song lyrics into a broadcast to describe Martians landing on Earth. Buchanan’s radio disc jockey character is based on Alan Freed.

The song uses clips from 17 different songs, all top 20 hits from 1955 or 1956. The section lists these songs in order of appearance, divided by side one and side two of the record. Artists include Nappy Brown, The Platters, The Teenagers featuring Frankie Lymon, Little Richard, Fats Domino, Elvis Presley, The Penguins, Smiley Lewis, Don Cherry, Carl Perkins, Chuck Berry, and Bill Haley & His Comets.

The section also highlights the song’s technological significance, comparing it to the work of musique concrÃ¨te composers like Pierre Schaeffer, Pierre Boulez, and Karlheinz Stockhausen, who also used tape manipulation in the early 1950s. It’s also described as an early, less avant-garde example of a sample collage, compared to James Tenney’s Collage #1.

Release and Reception ðŸ”—

The extensive sampling in “The Flying Saucer” led to copyright lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman in July 1956. The duo faced criticism, but they responded with a follow-up song, “Buchanan and Goodman on Trial.” In November 1956, a judge ruled the song artful and clever, refusing to issue an injunction against sales. This ruling was significant because it essentially considered the record a new work, paving the way for legal sampling.

Following the single and the trial record, Buchanan and Goodman created more “Flying Saucer” records, forming a “UFO comedy series.” Other artists, including Dewey, George and Jack and the Belltones, Alan Freed, Steve Allen, Al “Jazzbo” Collins and the Modernaires, and Sid Noel, released their own versions of “The Flying Saucer.” The success of “The Flying Saucer” increased sales of songs excerpted in the pastiche, such as The Penguins’ “Earth Angel” and Little Richard’s “Long Tall Sally.”

Legacy ðŸ”—

“The Flying Saucer” is recognized as the first song to sample the work of other artists. It’s considered an early instance of sampling and industry litigation. The lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman made them trailblazers in sampling and related litigation. The song is considered a musical concept that is now a part of popular music. It is also considered the first acknowledged example of a mashup.

The song paved the way for artists like Public Enemy, Freelance Hellraiser, Negativland, and Danger Mouse, who also faced litigation for sample-based copyright infringement. Steinski cited “The Flying Saucer” as a formative influence. The record’s influence stretches to pop music built on samplings and comedy routines that take answers out of context.

Charts ðŸ”—

This section provides the chart performance of “The Flying Saucer,” noting that it reached a peak position of 3 on the US Best Sellers in Stores chart in Billboard in 1956.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Flying_Saucer_(song)

item.title: Roswell That Ends Well
item.description:
Roswell That Ends Well ðŸ”—

“Roswell That Ends Well” is the 19th episode of the third season of the animated television series Futurama. It originally aired on December 9, 2001.

Plot ðŸ”—

The Planet Express crew, while observing a supernova, accidentally time travel to 1947 after Fry microwaves a metal pan of popcorn. They crash-land in Roswell, New Mexico, becoming part of the Roswell Incident. Bender is shattered upon impact. The crew searches for a way back to the 31st century. Zoidberg is captured by the U.S. military and experimented on at Roswell Air Base. The military reconstructs Bender’s body into a flying saucer.

The crew needs a microwave oven to return to their time. Professor Farnsworth warns Fry against interacting with his grandfather, Enos, to avoid a grandfather paradox. Fry tries to protect Enos, but Enos dies in a nuclear weapon test. Fry sleeps with Mildred, Enos’s fiancÃ©e, and realizes she is his grandmother, making him his own grandfather.

The crew storms Roswell Air Base to steal a microwave dish. Fry and Leela rescue Zoidberg from an alien autopsy. Farnsworth retrieves Bender’s body. While time jumping, Bender’s head is left behind. Back in the 31st century, the crew returns to Roswell, finds Bender’s head, and reattaches it to his body.

Production ðŸ”—

The writing team developed the episode from ideas initially considered for “Anthology of Interest II.” The writers initially avoided time travel in Futurama, but changed their minds. They made the time travel unintentional, triggered by a supernova, to avoid regular time travel. The episode was directed by Rich Moore, who used screen position and character movement to represent time travel. Actions to the left represented the past, while actions to the right indicated progress.

Cultural references ðŸ”—

The episode references time travel stories like Back to the Future and Terminator. It also shares similarities with the Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode “Little Green Men.” Bender’s head buried in the sand is similar to Data’s head in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Enos’s character is based on Gomer Pyle.

Broadcast and reception ðŸ”—

“Roswell That Ends Well” won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (Programming Less Than One Hour) in 2002. Rich Moore won an Annie Award for directing. IGN ranked it as one of the best Futurama episodes. David X. Cohen considered it one of his favorite episodes. Sci Fi Weekly gave it an “A” grade. Despite critical acclaim, the episode had low ratings during its original airing.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_That_Ends_Well

item.title: Ancient astronauts in popular culture
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts in Popular Culture ðŸ”—

This article explores the presence of the ancient astronaut theory in various forms of fiction, including literature, comics, television, film, documentaries, music, and video games. The theory posits that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in the distant past and influenced the development of human civilization.

Literature ðŸ”—

This section details numerous literary works that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Les Xipehuz (1887) by J.-H. Rosny aÃ®nÃ©: Features geometric aliens encountered by primitive humans.
  • Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) by Garrett P. Serviss: Martians enslaved inhabitants of the Fertile Crescent and used them to build monuments in Egypt.
  • The Call of Cthulhu (1926) and At the Mountains of Madness (1931) by H.P. Lovecraft: Deals with ancient aliens.
  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968) by Arthur C. Clarke: Based on his short story “Encounter in the Dawn,” explores the idea of extraterrestrial influence on human evolution.
  • The Sirens of Titan (1959) by Kurt Vonnegut: Human development is manipulated by aliens to relay messages.
  • Known Space (1964â€“present) by Larry Niven: Humanity is descended from aliens called the Pak.
  • Heechee Saga (1972â€“2004) by Frederik Pohl: The Heechee are an ancient alien race that left behind futuristic technology.
  • Uplift Universe (1980-…) by David Brin: Explores the idea that all species were brought to sapience through the intervention of a galactic “patron.”
  • VALIS trilogy (1981) by Philip K. Dick: An ancient astronaut race placed an information-streaming satellite in orbit around Earth.
  • Encounter With Tiber (1996) by Buzz Aldrin and John Barnes: Deals with the discovery of ancient alien encounters on Earth and Mars.
  • Outlanders novel series (1997-…) by Mark Ellis: The Anunnaki are revealed to have been behind a nuclear war and the Root Race of the Gray aliens.

Comics ðŸ”—

This section highlights comic books and series that feature ancient astronauts or related concepts. Some notable examples include:

  • Uncle Scrooge #34 (1961): A Carl Barks story where Scrooge McDuck’s family discovers a planetoid inhabited by beings who were the basis for Roman and Norse gods.
  • Tales of Suspense #50 (1964): Introduces the Mandarin’s rings, created by the alien Makluans.
  • The Adventures of Tintin: Flight 714 to Sydney (1968) by HergÃ©: Features a temple built to honor ancient astronauts.
  • The Eternals: Deals with advanced aliens (the Celestials) who experimented on early hominids, creating the Eternals and Deviants.
  • Thorgal series by Grzegorz RosiÅ„ski and Van Hamme: The main protagonist is the son of ancient astronauts.
  • KarmatrÃ³n y los Transformables by Oscar GonzÃ¡lez Loyo: Relies heavily on the ancient astronaut theory.

Television ðŸ”—

This section details television shows that have explored the ancient astronaut theme. Some key examples include:

  • Quatermass and the Pit (1958â€“1959): A miniseries that used a version of the ancient astronaut idea.
  • Star Trek: The franchise has numerous examples of extraterrestrials visiting Earth in past centuries, influencing pre-modern humans.
  • Doctor Who: Pyramids of Mars (1975): Features a conflict between aliens of a race named the Osirans forming the basis of Egyptian mythology.
  • Space: 1999 (1975â€“1977): Many alien species have controlled or visited Earth in the past.
  • Battlestar Galactica: Depicts humans as having originated on the planet Kobol and later settled thirteen colony planets, Earth being the last and most distant.
  • Babylon 5 (1993â€“1998): Many of the First Ones, particularly the Vorlons and Shadows, visited Earth at various times in history.
  • The X-Files (1993â€“2002, 2016â€“2018): Has borrowed the ancient astronaut theory.
  • Earth: Final Conflict (1997â€“2002): The Atavus species traveled to Earth in the distant past and ruled over it.
  • The Super Dimension Fortress Macross (1982): Features an ancient alien civilization called The Protoculture, who created the human race on Earth.
  • Neon Genesis Evangelion: Lilith and Adam were two extraterrestrial beings that landed on Earth and gave birth to humanity.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists films that incorporate the ancient astronaut theory. Some notable examples include:

  • 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968): The first act of the movie features paleocontact.
  • Horror Express (1972): An extraterrestrial is found frozen for millions of years.
  • Alien vs. Predator (2004): The Predator race traveled to Earth at a prehistoric time and had a human culture serve them as Gods.
  • Prometheus (2012): Themed around a group of scientists who set out to discover the origins of human life, which was seeded on Earth and influenced by an ancient race of aliens.
  • Hangar 18 (1980): Involves a UFO whose symbols are found to match those used in ancient cultures.
  • Stargate (1994): Features Ra, a member of the alien species Goa’uld that came to Earth around 8000 BC, enslaved the ancient Egyptians, adopting their culture and religion and posing as their God.
  • Mission to Mars (2000): Another movie with an “alien seeding” theme.
  • Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008): Links the existence of crystal skulls to beings that were perceived as gods by the Maya civilization.

Documentaries ðŸ”—

This section lists documentaries that explore the ancient astronaut theory.

  • Chariots of the Gods (1970)
  • In Search of Ancient Astronauts (1973)
  • In Search of Ancient Mysteries (1974)
  • The Outer Space Connection (1975)

Music ðŸ”—

This section highlights musical works that deal with the ancient astronaut concept.

  • A Spaceman Came Travelling by Chris de Burgh: Deals with the concept of an ancient astronaut, in this case pertaining to the Christ story.
  • Inca Roads by Frank Zappa: Deals with Ancient Astronaut Theory.
  • Several songs by The Lost Children of Babylon: Explicitly state that “Jesus Christ was really an ancient astronaut.”
  • God Is an Astronaut: A post-rock musical group from Ireland with a name exploiting the theory.
  • Ayreon albums: About ancient astronauts, that go by the name Forever, who traveled from the Andromeda Galaxy to earth long ago and influenced the development of science and technology.

Video Games ðŸ”—

This section lists video games that incorporate the ancient astronaut theme.

  • Spore (2008): Has many elements of ancient astronauts, even giving player the ability to manipulate other less developed species as a space travelling species.
  • Final Fantasy VII: Features an ancient astronaut, Jenova, as the main antagonist.
  • Halo series: Ancient humanity was a spacefaring society technologically superior to modern humanity.
  • Dark Void: Features a race of humanoid shape-shifters called Watchers, who ruled over ancient humans as gods.
  • Mass Effect: Humanity discovers a cache of alien technology built by an alien species known as the Protheans.
  • Assassin’s Creed franchise: Humanity was originally created as a slave race by the “First Civilization.”
  • Rise of Nations: Rise of Legends: The Cuotl is a nation of Mesoamerica-inspired tribes subjugated by four extraterrestrial beings who install themselves as deities.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts_in_popular_culture

item.title: List of alien races in DC Comics
item.description:
List of alien races in DC Comics ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive list of extraterrestrial races that have appeared in DC Comics, including comic book titles and other media properties. It provides brief descriptions and citations for each race.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section lists all the sections in the article, organized alphabetically. It includes links to each section for easy navigation.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a general introduction to the topic, noting the vast number of extraterrestrial races in the DC Comics universe and that most are humanoid.

United Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the United Planets, a governing body active from the 21st to the 31st centuries. It mentions known members like planets of the Solar System, Htrae, artificial planet-sized satellites, buffer planets seeded by Mon-El, and neighboring empires. It also notes that in the 21st century, the United Planets are led by the corrupt Durlan Thaaros. This section is marked as needing expansion.

0-9 ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with a number.

5th Dimensional Imps ðŸ”—

This section details the 5th Dimensional Imps, who originate from the planet Zrfff. Notable Imps include Mister Mxyzptlk, Miss Gsptlsnz, Vyndktvx, Brpxz, Mister Genie (Genro), Quisp, Bat-Mite, Kcid Nosyarg (Larry), Zook, Gazook, and Mopee.

5th Dimensional Imps in other media ðŸ”—

This section lists appearances of 5th Dimensional Imps in other media, such as the Supergirl TV series, where Mxyzptlk and Gsptlsnz/Nyxlygsptlnz appear. It also mentions the Music Meister being revealed as an imp in a Supergirl crossover with The Flash.

A ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “A”.

Adaptoids ðŸ”—

This section describes the Adaptoids, blob-like creatures from near Arcturus that attempted to wipe out the human race on Earth-One. They were defeated by the Justice League when exposed to the Thanagarian equalizing disease.

Aellans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Aellans, yellow-skinned reptilian humanoids from Aello (Stormswift). Demonia, Harpis and Doc of Aello were all members of the Omega Men.

Alien Invaders ðŸ”—

This section describes the Alien Invaders, the nameless primary antagonists of Armageddon: The Alien Agenda.

Almeraci ðŸ”—

This section details the Almeraci, a humanoid race of technologically advanced warriors with psionic abilities. They are ruled by the matriarchal House of the Blood Royale, which maintains its bloodline through selective breeding. Key members include Maxima (Queen of Almerac), her handmaiden Sazu, and Ultraa.

Aloi ðŸ”—

This section describes the Aloi, blue-skinned aliens with ridged foreheads at war with the Margoi over a device called the “Grayl”. They are represented by Tumlat.

Alstairans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Alstairans of Alstair, one of four technologically advanced spacefaring races native to the Antares system. They are plantlike humanoids with leaves instead of hair, and their ruler is Hyathis.

Anasazi ðŸ”—

This section describes the Anasazi, metahumans who were resettled to the planet Starhaven. Dawnstar represents this species.

Andromedans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Andromedans of the Andromeda Galaxy, a race of superhumans similar to Kryptonians and Daxamites. They have red hair, albino skin, and blue eyes. Karb-Brak, an Andromedan exiled to Earth, was eventually cured and returned to his homeworld.

Angtuans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Angtuans, inhabitants of the planet Angtu, which was destroyed by Mano in the 30th century.

Anunnake ðŸ”—

This section describes the Anunnake, reptilian aliens who claim to have killed off the dinosaurs and are also known as the Hunter/Gatherers.

Anndrann ðŸ”—

This section describes the Anndrann, green-skinned military geniuses from Anndranna, famed for their weapons of war. Iron has a deleterious effect on their cognitive abilities.

Appellaxians ðŸ”—

This section details the Appellaxians of Appellax, technologically advanced energy aliens with the ability to create powerful artificial host bodies. The seven Appellaxians that invaded created bodies named Golden Roc, Wood King, Stone-God, Crystal Creature, Fire-Lord, Glass-Man, and Mercury Monster. Their invasion led to the formation of the Justice League.

Appellaxians in other media ðŸ”—

This section lists appearances of the Appellaxians’ creations in other media, such as the Young Justice episode “Salvage,” where Bruno Mannheim combines them into a Golem.

Aipitons ðŸ”—

This section describes the Aipitons, a species of small flying insects from the planet Apaiton, represented by the deceased Green Lantern Bzzd.

Aquoids ðŸ”—

This section describes the Aquoids, natives of planet Beltair IV.

Aranes ðŸ”—

This section describes the Aranes of Arane II, light blue-skinned humanoids with white hair and tiny blue horns. Rolind Siepur of Arane II is a member of the Dark Circle.

Ardenans ðŸ”—

This section describes the Ardenans, sentient humanoids with orange scaly skin from the planet Arden, represented by the deceased Green Lanterns Lodar and Meeno Monak.

Astonians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Astonians, a minor alien race saved from extinction by the Blue Lantern Saint Walker, who is of this race.

Azarathians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Azarathians, people belonging to the parallel universe of Azarath. Raven is an Azarathian.

B ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “B”.

Barrions ðŸ”—

This section describes the Barrions of Barrio III, silicon-based lifeforms represented by the Green Lantern Chaselon.

Bellatrix Bombers ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bellatrix Bombers, alien warlords featured in Green Lantern (vol. 3) #20.

Bgztlians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bgztlians, humans from the colony Bgztl who possess the metahuman ability of intangibility. Phantom Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes represents them.

Blight ðŸ”—

This section describes the Blight, a cybernetic race whose bodies are composed of rotting flesh and villains of the Legion of Super-Heroes. Their leader is Atrophos.

Bloodline Parasites ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bloodline Parasites, extraterrestrial lifeforms capable of activating the human metagene while feeding on spinal fluid. They have dense exoskeletons, are incredibly strong, and can duplicate human form.

Braalians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Braalians, humans from the colony Braal who possess the metahuman ability of electromagnetic field manipulation. Cosmic Boy and Magno of the Legion of Super-Heroes represent them.

Brain-Parasites of Planet X ðŸ”—

This section describes the Brain-Parasites of Planet X, who use Knowledge-Extractors to steal knowledge from other races.

Branx ðŸ”—

This section describes the Branx of Emana Branx, a gray-skinned race of dull-witted, four-armed warriors who serve the Citadelians.

Brylyx ðŸ”—

This section describes the Brylyx, white-skinned aliens featured in Green Lantern: Mosaic.

The Bolovax Vikians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bolovax Vikians, a highly communal and technologically advanced race from Bolovax Vik, now a dead race. Kilowog of the Green Lantern Corps is the last surviving member.

Bolovax Vikians in other media ðŸ”—

This section notes the appearance of a holographic Bolovax Vikian in the My Adventures with Superman episode “The Machine Who Would Be Empire”.

Bugs of New Genesis ðŸ”—

This section describes the Bugs of New Genesis, an insectoid race who thrive in colonies beneath the surface of the planet. Forager and Mantis are prominent members.

C ðŸ”—

This section lists alien races whose names begin with the letter “C”.

Cairnians ðŸ”—

This section mentions the Cairnians as members of L.E.G.I.O.N.

Calatonians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Calatonians, an ancient monarchy on the planet Calaton ravaged by the Doomsday creature.

Canopians ðŸ”—

This section mentions the Canopians as members of Atari Force. Canopians such as Morphea are from New Earth in a parallel universe.

Carggites ðŸ”—

This section describes the Carggites, humans from the colony Cargg who possess the metahuman ability of duplication. Triplicate Girl of the Legion of Super-Heroes represents them.

Catherix ðŸ”—

This section describes the Cathexis, alien super-scientists from the “sixth dimension” who created self-aware reality endangering technology.

Changralynians ðŸ”—

This section describes the Changralynians of Changralyn, a race of silicon-based pacifists represented by Broot of the Omega Men.

Chietain ðŸ”—

This section is marked as needing expansion.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martian_(DC_Comics)

item.title: Alien TV (2019 TV series)
item.description:
Alien TV (2019 TV series) ðŸ”—

Alien TV is a live-action/CG animation television series that premiered on 9Go! in Australia on November 23, 2019, and on Netflix. The show was created by Ian Brown and developed by Doug Hadders and Adam Rotstein. The series follows a television news crew of extraterrestrials named Ixbee, Pixbee, and Squee, who are sent to Earth to learn about the planet.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main voice cast includes Rob Tinkler as Ixbee, Julie Lemieux as Pixbee, John Cleland as Squee, Kyle Dooley as Squood, and Rupert Degas as the Translator.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of two seasons. Season 1 was released on August 21, 2020, and Season 2 was released on March 19, 2021. There are no plans for a season 3.

Series Overview ðŸ”—

The series is divided into two seasons, with 13 episodes each. Season 1 was released in 2020, and Season 2 in 2021. Each episode contains three segments.

Season 1 (2020) ðŸ”—

Season 1 consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. Each segment focuses on the aliens’ experiences with different aspects of Earth culture and activities, such as bicycles, gymnastics, camping, playgrounds, art, gum, gyms, birthdays, restaurants, BBQs, offices, Halloween, pizza, magic, cleaning, arcades, dumplings, presents, junkyards, spas, love, movies, kindergarten, sickness, babies, supermarkets, tea, weddings, Loch Ness, soccer, skateboards, mannequins, survival, toyshops, laundromats, yoga, Santa, trophies, and makeup. Each segment is directed by Ian Brown and written by various writers, including Doug Hadders, Adam Rotstein, Jeff Sager, Brian Hartigan, Shawn Kalb, Cleon Prineas, Laurie Elliott, Bruce Griffiths, Simon Dodd, Jennifer Daley, Thomas Duncan-Watt and Naomi Jardine.

Season 2 (2021) ðŸ”—

Season 2 also consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. The segments continue to explore the aliens’ interactions with Earth, featuring topics such as trains, barbershops, gnomes, florists, fashion, teeth, pools, dinner parties, skiing, joke shops, the Outback, fire halls, baby showers, yard sales, aquariums, dance, international games, shopping, school, holidays, lucha libre, cars, sleep, golf, airplanes, water parks, mail, music, bowling, gardening, museums, Bollywood, castles, ballet, energy, leprechauns, glasses, trials, and scary things. Ian Brown directs all segments, and the writing credits include Naomi Jardine, Jerome Simpson, Bruce Griffiths, Jennifer Daley, Jeff Sager, Kyle Dooley, Simon Dodd, Cleon Prineas, Brian Hartigan, and Gina Roncoli Bruce Griffiths.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_TV

item.title: Kecksburg UFO incident
item.description:
Kecksburg UFO Incident ðŸ”—

The Kecksburg UFO incident occurred on December 9, 1965, in Kecksburg, Pennsylvania. A fireball was seen across six U.S. states and Canada. While astronomers suggested it was a meteor bolide, the event gained notoriety in popular culture and ufology. Speculation ranged from an extraterrestrial craft to debris from the Soviet space probe Kosmos 96. It’s often referred to as “Pennsylvania’s Roswell.” NASA released a statement in 2005 suggesting fragments were from a Soviet satellite, but records were reportedly lost.

Initial Reports ðŸ”—

On the evening of December 9, 1965, a large fireball was observed across multiple U.S. states and Ontario, Canada, particularly over the Detroit-Windsor area. Reports included hot metal debris in Michigan and Ohio, grass fires, and sonic booms near Pittsburgh. Residents of Kecksburg, Pennsylvania, reported blue smoke, vibrations, a “thump,” and a crash in the woods. Early reports in the Greensburg Tribune-Review mentioned the area being sealed off by U.S. Army and State Police officials. However, a subsequent search by state troopers and Air Force personnel found nothing. Authorities dismissed explanations like a plane crash or missile test, attributing it to a meteor. Astronomer Paul Annear and geophysicist George Wetherilo supported the meteor explanation, as did astronomers William P. Bidelman and Fred Hess.

Scientific Articles ðŸ”—

This section references scientific articles written about the fireball in science journals.

Sky & Telescope ðŸ”—

The February 1966 issue of Sky & Telescope reported the fireball’s sighting over the Detroit-Windsor area around 4:44 p.m. EST. The FAA received 23 reports from aircraft pilots starting at the same time. A seismograph near Detroit recorded shock waves. The article concluded the fireball’s path extended from northwest to southeast, ending near western Lake Erie.

Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada ðŸ”—

A 1967 article in the Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada (JRASC) by two astronomers used seismographic records to pinpoint the time of passage over Detroit to 4:43 p.m. Photographs taken north of Detroit were used to triangulate the object’s trajectory. The conclusion was that the fireball descended at a steep angle, moving from southwest to northeast, likely impacting the northwestern shore of Lake Erie near Windsor, Ontario.

NASA Statements ðŸ”—

In December 2005, NASA released a statement claiming experts examined metallic fragments from the area and determined they were from a Soviet satellite that re-entered the atmosphere, but records were lost in the 1980s. Leslie Kean, an investigative reporter, sued NASA under the Freedom of Information Act for the lost records. In 2007, NASA was ordered by a court to search for the records. During a hearing, NASA’s public liaison officer, Steve McConnell, testified that two boxes of relevant papers were missing. James Oberg suggested the NASA team might have been Air Force personnel posing as NASA, and that Kean’s action was a publicity stunt. John Ventre of MUFON and Owen Eichler speculated the object was a General Electric Mark 2 Re-entry Vehicle. More recent NASA comments suggest the fireball’s trajectory was inconsistent with a spacecraft re-entering from Earth orbit, more likely a meteor from the asteroid belt, and that U.S. Air Force tracking data indicated Cosmos 96 decayed earlier.

Television and Film ðŸ”—

This section details the appearances of the Kecksburg UFO incident in various television shows and films.

  • In 1990, Unsolved Mysteries aired an episode suggesting an extraterrestrial craft crashed, with locals reporting an acorn-shaped object with hieroglyphs, removed in a secret military operation. A prop from the show is displayed in Kecksburg.
  • In 2003, the Sci Fi Channel aired “The New Roswell: Kecksburg Exposed,” featuring a Kecksburg resident claiming to have seen a flat-bed truck carrying something “the size of a VW.”
  • In 2008, Nazi UFO Conspiracy suggested the incident was the recovery of a Nazi UFO called Die Glocke.
  • In 2009, UFO Hunters suggested a military conspiracy and cover-up.
  • In 2011, Ancient Aliens suggested Die Glocke was recovered at Kecksburg, prompting a government conspiracy.
  • In 2014, In Search of Aliens visited the crash site with UFO researcher Stan Gordon.
  • In 2019, Cody Knotts premiered his film Kecksburg, dramatizing the story of a reporter claiming to be a victim of a government conspiracy.
  • Andrew Patterson cited the Kecksburg incident as partial inspiration for his 2019 film The Vast of Night.
  • BBC Radio 4’s 2024 drama series, Limelight: The Skies Are Watching, uses the Kecksburg incident as its inspiration.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section lists related topics, including a list of UFO sightings and Die Glocke (conspiracy theory).

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kecksburg_UFO_incident
